Award.AwardTitle: Management and Operation of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, 2008-2018, and Supporting Activities (NGIC)

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report represents projects that are funded by the National Ground Intelligence Center (NGIC) and awarded through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Cooperative Agreement to the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) for the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).

NCAR scientists continue to support the  National Ground Intelligence Center (NGIC) in its mission of assessing the consequences of the transport and dispersion of accidental and intentional releases of hazardous materials into the atmosphere. This is done by providing the agency with access to the NCAR developed GCAT (Global Climate Analysis Toolkit) system. GCAT is a fully-automated dynamical downscaling system that allows NGIC scientists to remotely generate a high-resolution 30-year climatography for any region on the Earth. GCAT is based upon Climate Four-Dimensional Data Assimilation (CFDDA) technologies and can run with four domains, reaching a grid increment of 1.1-km. This enables NGIC to conduct transport and dispersion analyses at very fine scale.  GCAT has the capability to automatically classify WRF output fields into climatological regimes.

This project focused on the continued development and maintenance of the GCAT,  a server-side software system, that allows the National Ground Intelligence Center to configure and generate high-resolution (3km) climatographies over limited domains anywhere in the world. NCAR scientists discovered that self-organizing map (SOM) clustering algorithms can be used to objectively classify climate patterns based upon meteorological state variables of interest (i.e. wind vectors). These patterns can then be used to identify typical days within the climate record that are characteristic of the parent patterns. The typical days are then used to provide physically consistent input to transport and dispersion models to evaluate typical dispersion patterns for atmospheric release of hazardous materials within each climate regime. Research efforts also indicated that use of NOAA's Climate Forecast System can be used to re-assess the frequency of occurrence of weather patterns with up to six months lead time. Output from GCAT is input into plume models, such as the Department of Defense (DOD) Hazard Prediction and Assessment Capability (HPAC) application. Results from the GCAT system directly inform DoD decisions related to forensic analysis of potentially deadly airborne chemical or biological hazards. The GCAT system is also used extensively by researchers in the university community to support their own sponsored research work.

Dissemination of techniques and findings to others in the field of artificial intelligence and machine learning has occurred through presentations by team scientific staff at conferences, meetings and workshops. Scientific results have also been published in peer-reviewed literature.
